filme.titulo: Bonnie e Clyde - Uma Rajada de Balas
filme.sinopse: A somewhat romanticized account of the career of the notoriously violent bank robbing couple and their gang.
filme.storyline: A bored small-town girl and a small-time bank robber leave in their wake a string of violent robberies and newspaper headlines that catch the imagination of the Depression-struck Mid-West in this take on the legendary crime spree of these archetypal lovers on the run.

review.conteudo: Bonnie Parker(played by Faye Dunaway) & Clyde Barrow(played by Warren Beatty) are a depression era couple who commit a brazen series of bank robberies across the Midwest. They are eventually joined by Clyde's brother Buck(played by Gene Hackman) his wife Blanche(Estelle Parsons) and a gas station attendant named C. W. Moss(Michael J. Pollard). All are on a collision course with a violent end as the manhunt(led by Denver Pyle) closes in on them... Popular and trend-setting film is ultimately all style over substance; well-acted by stars playing unlikable people who deserve what they get. Film seems to be as along for the ride as the supporting characters, rather than portraying their dead-end and violent crime spree as something to be condemned. Imagine the film told from the POV of the authorities to see what I mean...

Bonnie and Clyde (1967) Bonnie and Clyde the people are now legends and the movie is just as legendary and respectable, unlike the people. Written with a lot of meat to its bones: emotionally, entertainingly, and intellectually, Bonnie and Clyde is a dazzling movie. There is something about the directing here that latches onto the viewer, bites them like a mosquito and then suddenly it consumes them. This movie is the mark of something special. It's a finely well- rounded in the way that it communicates to the audience and what its saying. Like the mosquito bite analogy, it sticks around for a while and stirs in your mind. Technically aside, it's a blast to watch, too. The title characters are one heck of a movie couple and are entertaining people to spend time with. Both lead performances contribute to the film's staggering success, and for me Warren Beatty delivers a volcanic smash of a portrayal and is one of the best things about the movie. As the writing, action, and romance, technically it was ahead of its time, thankfully, which make the many action scenes stand and significant. Bonnie and Clyde is a captivating film that stands as one of the defining movies that advanced the industry and the genre of action movies. Rating: 9.5/10 Grade: A

In taking a good look at the movies that made American cinema in one way or the other, "Bonnie And Clyde" glitters in its own way. It's one of the very first films that started the New Hollywood movement, one of the most dense periods in the history of film. Based on the real story of Bonnie and Clyde, two bank robbers active in 1930's Texas, the film stars Warren Beatty (who also produces) and Faye Dunaway, in her first major role. Clyde has just been released in prison when he meets Bonnie by chance. Immediately fascinated by the exciting lifestyle Clyde has to endure, she flees with him, and together they run all over the American South robbing banks. Along with them they soon pick up a timid mechanic to help them, and Clyde's brother Buck meets them and joins them along with his wife. The five of them are now famed by the press and are being hunted all over, so it becomes harder and harder for the bunch to find peace for even one night. Beatty and Dunaway's duet is almost iconic now: together, Bonnie and Clyde symbolize the "gangster couple" that many films have been inspired by years later. Although the honor of best actor in the film would have to go to Gene Hackman playing Buck, the couple steals the screen and wins the favor of the audience from the get-go. But the movie has been influential also for its visual style, a credit to be attributed to director Arthur Penn, who was on his fifth film. Violence here was considered graphic and especially crude at the time, and as a consequence it initiated the trend of highlighting violence during the New Hollywood years, a trend that still today is extremely popular and is even more highlighted and crude. Sex plays another controversial factor, not really for its depiction ( there's not much to see), but for the fact that Clyde seems almost asexual and not willing to engage in a romance with Bonnie. Of course, this is not one of the most popular kind of relationships seen on the big screen. "Bonnie And Clyde" has aged perfectly well, and although it's not a movie with much replay value in this reviewer's eyes, it still ought to hold the important position it currently holds in movie history. It's to say the least that it's been an influential picture for many, and represents the beginning of an essential chapter of American pop culture.
